awd_titl_txt: Photoionization and Photoelectron Spectroscopy of Transient Organometallic Complexes
awd_abstract_narration:
Saturated hydrocarbons or alkanes constitute the most abundant feedstock for organic chemicals. Controlling which bonds in hydrocarbons react with other molecules (also known as "selective activation and functionalization") remains one of the grand challenges in the chemical sciences. In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms A (CSDM-A) Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Dong-Sheng Yang of the University of Kentucky contributes to this task by examining the way metal atoms interact with the hydrocarbon compounds and detecting reactive chemical species in these reactions using laboratory-made instruments and sophisticated laser spectroscopic techniques. Professor Yang-s research shows how the hydrocarbons are activated by metals and converted into other chemicals. This work improves the fundamental understanding about how metal catalysts increase the rate of a chemical reaction and reduce the energy required for hydrocarbon conversion. The project provides technically challenging training for a diverse group of students at all levels and prepares them for careers in industry, academia, or the public sector.

The projects focuses on spectroscopic characterization of transient organometallic complexes formed in metal-mediated alkane activation reactions. Emphasis is placed on the C-H and C-C bond activation of small alkanes and the remote functionalization of alkyl nitriles, amines, and alcohols by lanthanide metals. Expected results are the accurate ionization energies, metal-ligand and ligand-based vibrational frequencies, electronic states, spin-orbit splitting, and molecular structures of the short-lived species. The plan is to examine the electron configuration effects of the lanthanide elements and the reactivity-structural relationships of the linear, branched, and cyclic alkanes and functionalized alkane derivatives. Experimental methods include laser-assisted molecular beam reactions; time-of-flight mass spectrometry; mass-analyzed threshold ionization, zero electron kinetic energy, and infrared-ultraviolet photoionization spectroscopy; and slow electron velocity-map imaging. The experimental measurements are supplemented with quantum chemical calculations. The students engaged in this project are being trained not only in the aforementioned experimental techniques, but also quantum chemistry calculations, namely density functional theory, as well as other advanced tools through collaboration with other experts (e.g., Prof. Michael Schmidt, Iowa State).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Hydrocarbons are the major constituents of petroleum and natural gas. The conversion of hydrocarbons into functionalized chemicals for daily or industrial uses is an important commercial process. Metal catalysis reduces energy consumptions and speeds up the process under mild conditions. This work discovered the way metal atoms interacted with hydrocarbons and their derivatives and showed how they were converted into other chemicals. The new knowledge from this work shall provide guidance for the design of selective and efficient catalysts. A catalyst is a substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without itself be consumed in the process. The project provided technically challenging training for a diverse group of students at all levels and prepares them for careers in industry, academia, or the public sector.

Results from this project produced numerous publications in professional journals and national or international professional conferences.  Specific scientific outcomes are the accurate ionization energies, metal-ligand and ligand-based vibrational energies, spin-orbit coupling, electronic states, molecular structures of short-lived metal-hydrocarbon complexes, and reaction pathways for the formation of the metal intermediates and products. The ionization energy is a basic thermochemical property of a molecule and is used to obtain the metal-ligand bond energy of the uncharged molecule through a thermodynamic relation. The metal-ligand vibrational energies give a direct evidence about the metal-ligand bonding, whereas the ligand-based vibrational frequencies probe the geometry of the metal-activated hydrocarbon fragments. The degree of the charge effect reveals the nature of the electron bonding in the highest molecular orbital. The knowledge about the formation,  bonding, structures, spin-orbit coupling, and electronic states of these reactive specie gives new insight into the dynamics and mechanisms of metal-activation reactions with hydrocarbons and provide benchmarks to test new or improved computational modelling on molecular properties.

The project trained young students in technically challenging fields and prepared them effectively in diverse sectors of technology-driven economy. The students have been trained in sophisticated instrumentation, state-of-the-art laser spectroscopy and imaging, and modern computational chemistry. They have been equipped with skills in the design, operation, and interpretation of scientific experiments and in the presentation and communication of research discoveries.
